update.description:
This is ready, test have been added.

This will allow ign-gazebo to be used as a library and allow plugins to be specified via ServerConfig.

# Testing

1. Install all the plugins from the [ign-plugins](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugins) repo.
2. Install the last of the [ign-tools prs](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools/pull-requests/9).
3. Install this PR.
4. Run `ign launch -f gazebo_plugins.ign`.
update.title: [A-7] Allow programmatic loading of plugins

content.raw: I think they're automatically added on purpose, because these are required parameters and not having them would be malformed SDF. Optional parameters don't get default values.
content.html: I think they're automatically added on purpose, because these are required parameters and not having them would be malformed SDF. Optional parameters don't get default values.

content.raw: But the thing to **really** strive for is [Rule of Zero](http://oliora.github.io/2015/12/29/pimpl-and-rule-of-zero.html).
content.html: But the thing to really strive for is Rule of Zero.

content.raw: The sensor system in ign-gazebo used to require unique names due to the way we’re looking up rendering::Cameras inside the system. But that’s not the case anymore. We’re now looking up the cameras based on their ids.
content.html: The sensor system in ign-gazebo used to require unique names due to the way we’re looking up rendering::Cameras inside the system. But that’s not the case anymore. We’re now looking up the cameras based on their ids.

content.raw: @scpeters also note that pull request #167 is adding an option to remove the entity types from the scoped name
content.html: @scpeters also note that pull request #167 is adding an option to remove the entity types from the scoped name

content.raw: The launch code and all plugins are now here: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/
content.html: The launch code and all plugins are now here: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/

content.raw:
I feel like `ign-launch-plugins` would be more accurate, since that seems to be the common denominator there. Things like the joystick for example don't depend on `ign-gazebo`.

The potential for this circular dependency is one of the reasons I think a design document would help clarify things, I agree with @iche033 that it's not clear when one should write an `ign-launch` plugin or an `ign-gazebo` one and what's their relationship.
content.html:
I feel like ign-launch-plugins would be more accurate, since that seems to be the common denominator there. Things like the joystick for example don't depend on ign-gazebo.

The potential for this circular dependency is one of the reasons I think a design document would help clarify things, I agree with @iche033 that it's not clear when one should write an ign-launch plugin or an ign-gazebo one and what's their relationship.

content.raw: For topics we're using the slashes, and when passing names to ign-sensors we're using `::` (not sure if that's required on the sensors side though).
content.html: For topics we're using the slashes, and when passing names to ign-sensors we're using :: (not sure if that's required on the sensors side though).

content.raw: Yup, I wasn't sure what we were going for so I made the delimiter optional.
content.html: Yup, I wasn't sure what we were going for so I made the delimiter optional.

content.raw:
if the plugins all require `ign-gazebo`, should we call it `ign-gazebo-plugins`?

do you want `ign-launch` to depend on `ign-gazebo`?
content.html:
if the plugins all require ign-gazebo, should we call it ign-gazebo-plugins?

do you want ign-launch to depend on ign-gazebo?

content.raw: though I see that the delimiter is an optional parameter; there is one test expectation that uses `::`, but the default appears to be `/`
content.html: though I see that the delimiter is an optional parameter; there is one test expectation that uses ::, but the default appears to be /

content.raw: We are using forward slashes now instead of double colons, right?
content.html: We are using forward slashes now instead of double colons, right?

content.raw: I'm going to leave as is since I don't have tests or a clear use-case to add the warning messages.
content.html: I'm going to leave as is since I don't have tests or a clear use-case to add the warning messages.

content.raw: That page is not saying that Rule of 5 is mandatory. It's saying that the Rule of 3 existed prior to C++11. Once C++11 came around the additional Rule 5 was created. A class can have no copy or move constructors (no rule), a copy constructor + assignment operator (Rule 3), *or* copy&move constructors and assigment and move operators.
content.html: That page is not saying that Rule of 5 is mandatory. It's saying that the Rule of 3 existed prior to C++11. Once C++11 came around the additional Rule 5 was created. A class can have no copy or move constructors (no rule), a copy constructor + assignment operator (Rule 3), or copy&move constructors and assigment and move operators.

content.raw: so you're using `/` instead of `::`? I like that
content.html: so you're using / instead of ::? I like that

content.raw: Thanks, @scpeters. Not sure if it helps, but we have a function to generate scoped names [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/db9d256f5ba629e3f3dc6a11b215ae1ec1bbfa72/src/Util_TEST.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Util_TEST.cc-37).
content.html: Thanks, @scpeters. Not sure if it helps, but we have a function to generate scoped names here.

content.raw: We have a helper function `scopedName` in `Util.hh` which returns the fully scoped name of any entity, following the Gazebo URI pattern (`type::name::type::name...`) and can output custom separators. See the [test](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/db9d256f5ba629e3f3dc6a11b215ae1ec1bbfa72/src/Util_TEST.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Util_TEST.cc-37) for examples. So far, it's mainly being used to generate default sensor topics, I think.
content.html: We have a helper function scopedName in Util.hh which returns the fully scoped name of any entity, following the Gazebo URI pattern (type::name::type::name...) and can output custom separators. See the test for examples. So far, it's mainly being used to generate default sensor topics, I think.

content.raw: Sorry, I'm talking about passing all the parameters one by one in the constructor. Note how `ServerConfig`'s parameters have to be set after construction. This makes it easier to deprecate / add parameters after the fact. For example, if we decide to change `entityType` to an enum someday, we'll need to change `PluginInfo`'s constructor.
content.html: Sorry, I'm talking about passing all the parameters one by one in the constructor. Note how ServerConfig's parameters have to be set after construction. This makes it easier to deprecate / add parameters after the fact. For example, if we decide to change entityType to an enum someday, we'll need to change PluginInfo's constructor.

content.raw: I've started work on the scoped name issue and am writing up a design document
content.html: I've started work on the scoped name issue and am writing up a design document

content.raw: Yup, I may be wrong, but I understand that the rule of 5 is the standard recommendation from C++11 onwards (note how Wikipedia says the rule of three is "prior to C++11").
content.html: Yup, I may be wrong, but I understand that the rule of 5 is the standard recommendation from C++11 onwards (note how Wikipedia says the rule of three is "prior to C++11").

content.raw: I'll leave it up to you. I think warnings / errors could make malformed plugins easier to debug.
content.html: I'll leave it up to you. I think warnings / errors could make malformed plugins easier to debug.

content.raw: I added a todo item instead: a93ca0d
content.html: I added a todo item instead: a93ca0d

content.raw:
I don't have a good way (yet), beside using world_name information, to specify a configuration per simulation runner. I don't believe it's urgent right now, but is something we should handle in the future. There is an asana task in blueprint for this.

The scoped name issue is also something that @scpeters  is interested in, related to SDF. We can tackle this first thing into the Blueprint development, again there is a new asana task.
content.html:
I don't have a good way (yet), beside using world_name information, to specify a configuration per simulation runner. I don't believe it's urgent right now, but is something we should handle in the future. There is an asana task in blueprint for this.

The scoped name issue is also something that @scpeters is interested in, related to SDF. We can tackle this first thing into the Blueprint development, again there is a new asana task.

content.raw: +1 for avoiding confusion between `ign-plugin` and `ign-plugins`. Seems like `ign-launch` would be a good place to put the plugins. Otherwise, maybe we can rename `ign-plugins` to `ign-tools-plugins`.
content.html: +1 for avoiding confusion between ign-plugin and ign-plugins. Seems like ign-launch would be a good place to put the plugins. Otherwise, maybe we can rename ign-plugins to ign-tools-plugins.
